description: Web Design I is a course designed to introduce the student to web presentation, theory, techniques and current software applications. Instruction will include usability, graphic design, web terminology, appropriate file protocoling, information architecture planning, communication strategies and www identity design. Upon completion of this course, students will possess a working knowledge of how to organize and design full web page content for interactive online user interfacing or control-group presentation.
name: WEB DESIGN

values.comments:
This course is designed to introduce the student to web presentation, theory, techniques and current software applications including Adobe Photoshop, Macromedia Dreamweaver and Macromedia Flash. Instruction also includes web terminology, appropriate file protocoling, information architecture planning, menu-linking organization, communication strategies and www identity design. Students can expect to gain a working knowledge of how to organize and design full web page content for interactive on-line user interfacing or control-group presentation by the end of the course.

Overall this course seemed to be well liked, although students complained that the material learned was focused on the technical aspects of web design and programming with little emphasis on critiques of design. Although students reported learning a lot in a small amount of time, some said they would have liked a little more time devoted to the aesthetics of design. 

Each student was impressed by Professor Buck’s ability to meet the differing needs of students. Some students had previous experience in programming, yet others had no knowledge of the software used in web design. Professor Buck was helpful and patient with these students, making sure everyone was able to follow along with the material and encouraging everyone to work at their own comfort level. Students also liked how she linked classroom material with real world applications. 

Grading was seen as fair and consistent, and lectures were organized and helpful. To summarize students’ opinions: the class is challenging and technical but rewarding. All classes can take this course, though FNAR 264 is a prerequisite. It is recommended to anyone that would like to learn more about web design and the basics of programming.
